title: 110_s2815
content:
The Act titled "Strengthening Student Aid for All Act" increases unsubsidized Stafford loan limits for undergraduate students. The "Strengthening Student Aid for All Act" raises the annual and aggregate loan limits for undergraduate dependent students under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The maximum annual loan amount is increased by $1,000, and the maximum aggregate loan amount is set at $29,500. The maximum annual amount of loans for undergraduate independent students is determined by specific criteria, including the length of the program. For students in their first 2 years of undergraduate study, the maximum amount is $6,000 for programs lasting at least one academic year. The maximum annual loan amount for undergraduate independent students is determined by program length. For students in their first 2 years of study, the maximum amount is $6,000 for programs lasting at least one academic year. If the program is less than one academic year, the loan amount is adjusted proportionally based on the program length. For students who have completed the first and second years but not the rest of the program, the maximum amount is $7,000. The maximum annual loan amount for undergraduate independent students is determined by program length. If the program is less than one academic year, the loan amount is adjusted proportionally based on the program length. For coursework specified in certain sections, the maximum amount is $6,000 for enrollment in an undergraduate degree or certificate program. The maximum loan amount for graduate or professional students is $57,500 under this section. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 specify changes for graduate students in loan provisions. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 impact loan provisions for graduate students, including redesignating subparagraphs and adjusting paragraph headings. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include in-school deferment of PLUS loans for parents of dependent students and the establishment of a secondary market of last resort for student loans. The Secretary serves as the secondary market of last resort for certain loans, buying them from eligible lenders at a specified price and holding and servicing them in a similar manner as other loans. The terms of the promissory note cannot be altered except as necessary to comply with specific requirements. The Secretary can buy a representative subset of loans from eligible lenders under specific sections, with a sunset provision set to expire on July 1, 2009, but can be extended if economic circumstances require it for continued access to student loans. The amendment allows for multiple extensions under specific conditions, each not exceeding 12 months. The amendment will take effect on the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. NEGATIVE EXPECTED FAMILY CONTRIBUTION. Amendments are made to sections 475 and 476 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 regarding dependent and independent students' assessments of adjusted available income. Amendments are made to section 477(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 regarding independent students with dependents other than a spouse. The changes include adjustments to the assessment of adjusted available income for these students. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include changes to the assessment of adjusted available income for independent students with dependents other than a spouse. This involves adjusting assessment schedules and rates, as well as simplifying needs tests. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 involve adjusting the assessment of adjusted available income for independent students with dependents other than a spouse. This includes changes to assessment schedules and rates, as well as simplifying needs tests. Additionally, there are amendments to the College Cost Reduction and Access Act regarding expected family contributions for Federal Pell Grants. The amendment allows students with a negative expected family contribution to receive a Federal Pell Grant equal to the maximum amount, an increase specified in the last appropriation Act, and an additional amount equal to the absolute value of their expected family contribution. The amendment ensures that if a student's expected family contribution is negative, their Federal Pell Grant cannot exceed their cost of attendance at the institution. Any excess amount will be reduced accordingly, with no other changes to the grant allocation formula. SEC. 6. LENDER-OF-LAST-RESORT. Section 428(j) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for students applying for loans at designated institutions in the State. Eligible borrowers attending these designated institutions can qualify for loans under this subsection. Additionally, an institution-wide student qualification requirement is added at the end of the section. The Secretary can designate institutions for participation in the lender-of-last-resort program, allowing eligible students to receive loans regardless of their ability to obtain loans elsewhere. The effective date for these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. MANDATORY ADVANCES: Amends Section 421(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 to authorize necessary appropriations for section 427(c)(7) implementation. Effective upon enactment. 

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE: Amendments take effect on July 1, 2008.
